channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Fayyad’s Resignation Means Uncertainty for Palestinians
item.description: The resignation of the Palestinian Authority’s prime minister, Salam Fayyad, adds a layer of confusion to the already contentious Palestinian political scene.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: The Palestinian Authority prime minister, Salam Fayyad, left, and President Mahmoud Abbas.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Assad Foes Hire Former British Diplomat to Plead Their Cause
item.description: Syria’s exiled opposition politicians are facing an uphill struggle to get firmer international help in winning the country’s civil war. They’ve taken on a New York-based adviser to help.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:credit: Filip Horvat for The New York Times

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: A ‘Gangnam Style’ Escape From Korean Tensions
item.description: Psy, the Korean pop sensation and creator of “Gangnam Style,” referred to North Korea during his Seoul concert on Saturday, amid some comic comparisons between him and the North Korean leader and some speculation he could be a peacemaker.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The Singer Psy performing his new single "Gentleman" in a concert titled "Happening" at the Olympic Stadium in Seoul.

item.title: New Bird Flu Cases Found in Central China
item.description: Two people in the central Chinese province of Henan have been infected by a new strain of avian influenza, the first cases found in the region, the state news agency said Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: China Makes Inroads in Nepal, Stemming Tibetan Presence
item.description: The Chinese are trying to stem the flow of disaffected Tibetans fleeing to Nepal and to enlist the help of the Nepalese in cracking down on the political activities of those already there.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: The stupa of a temple in Katmandu.

item.title: Kerry Arrives in China Seeking Help on North Korea
item.description: Amid fears that North Korea is ready to launch a medium-range missile, the United States is trying to enlist China’s assistance in defusing tensions.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry greeting China’s foreign minister, Wang Yi, on Saturday in Beijing.

item.title: Salam Fayyad, Palestinian Prime Minister, Resigns
item.description: Prime Minister Salam Fayyad had clashed politically with Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Western-backed Palestinian Authority, which governs the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Salam Fayyad of the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank city of Ramallah in January.

item.title: Sierra Leone Graft Charges Imperil Care and Aid
item.description: The top leadership of the Healthy Ministry faces charges of misusing foreign funds, raising alarm in a nation with the region’s worst health statistics.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Children bathing at a sawmill drainage pipe in Freetown amid a cholera emergency last year. The country has among the worst health statistics in the world and relies heavily on foreign aid.

item.title: Michel Djotodia, Leader of Coup in Central African Republic, Holds On to Power
item.description: Michel Djotodia, a wily opportunist who conducted a coup d’état in the Central African Republic in March, continues to hold the presidency, despite an international outcry.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:description: Michel Djotodia declared himself president of the Central African Republic in a March coup. Governments around the world have refused to recognize him as a legitimate head of state.

item.title: Tensions Turn Violent at Guantánamo Prison
item.description: A military news release said that the commander of the prison task force ordered the raid “to ensure the health and safety” of detainees.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: The Lede: North Korea Threatens Colorado City, Inaccurately
item.description: A video released on a North Korean government Web site shows the nation targeting nuclear weapons at a Colorado city. But a map shown places the city in the vicinity of Louisiana.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: Prototype: Watsi, a Crowdfunding Site, Offers Help With Medical Care
item.description: Watsi, a start-up founded by a former Peace Corps volunteer, is using crowdfunding to provide health care to patients in third-world countries.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLE LaPORTE
item.media:description: Chase Adam, 26, a former Peace Corps volunteer, is the founder of Watsi.

item.title: Sala Fayyad, Palestinian Prime Minister, Resigns
item.description: Prime Minister Salam Fayyad had clashed politically with Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Western-backed Palestinian Authority, which governs the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Salam Fayyad of the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank city of Ramallah in January.

item.title: Hackers Reveal Witness Names in Hariri Murder Trial
item.description: Hackers plastered the names of the so-called secret witnesses in the murder trial in the death of the former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri on a major Lebanese news Web site.
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: A Push Against Tax Havens Gains Support in Europe
item.description: A crackdown against tax evasion could eventually extend to dividends, capital gains and royalties, significantly expanding the revenue earned by national treasuries.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Patricia McCormick, Bullfighter Who Defied Gender Roles, Dies at 83
item.description: Ms. McCormick, the first woman from North America to be a professional bullfighter, performed in hundreds of bullfights in the 1950s and received top billing in stadiums worldwide.
item.dc:creator: By BRYAN MEALER
item.media:description: Patricia McCormick in 1955 in Tijuana, Mexico. She performed in hundreds of bullfights.

item.title: The Texas Tribune: Heavier Trucks From Mexico Could Prove Boon for Texas
item.description: A Texas lawmaker has filed legislation that would allow trucks to pay an $80 fee in exchange for crossing the border overweight.
item.dc:creator: By AMAN BATHEJA
item.media:credit: Photographs by Doug Young for The Texas Tribune
item.media:description: From left, a worker sorts limes at the McAllen Produce Terminal; a bin of Mexican watermelons; Carlos Zambito, the terminal’s marketing director.

item.title: Pope Francis Names Advisory Panel at Vatican
item.description: Vatican experts said the move was a strong sign that Francis was eager to consult widely and promote greater dialogue between the Vatican hierarchy and churches worldwide.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI and RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:description: Pope Francis with worshipers last week in St. Peter’s Square. His naming of advisers was seen as a move toward more collegial governance.

item.title: Syrian Forces Kill 12 Rebels in an Ambush
item.description: The government troops were trying to relieve a besieged military base in the country’s northwest.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Russia Bars 18 Americans After Sanctions by U.S.
item.description: A day after the United States imposed sanctions, Moscow responded with a list of Americans linked to prosecutions against Russian citizens and harsh interrogation methods.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Left and center, Melissa Golden/Getty Images; right, Damir Sagolj/Reuters
item.media:description: David Addington, left, John Yoo, center, and Maj. Gen. Geoffrey D. Miller are among those whom Russia has barred. The action from Moscow followed sanctions by the United States.

item.title: Mubarak, More Confident, Appears in Court in Cairo
item.description: Hosni Mubarak, Egypt’s former president, appeared to display new confidence in court, or perhaps a certain schadenfreude, as he appeared at a hearing to open his retrial.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:description: Gamal Mubarak, left, with his father, Hosni Mubarak, Egypt's former president, in a cage inside the courtroom during the elder Mr. Mubarak's trial in Cairo on Saturday.

item.title: ‘Django’ Expected Back in Chinese Theaters
item.description: After being pulled on its first day of release, the film “Django Unchained” is likely to undergo slight cuts for the Chinese market.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL CIEPLY

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: First Tastes of the 2012 Bordeaux
item.description: This is definitely a vintage to taste before buying. But tasting hundreds of reds in a day? Teeth stained, tongue hurting, you end up resembling a character in a teenage vampire movie, though you feel considerably older.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC PFANNER
item.media:description: Opening week for 2012 wines in the hall of the Bordeaux stock exchange.

item.title: Kim Jong-un Tests Relations With China
item.description: Chinese news media openly discuss the souring alliance and some see Kim Jong-un’s youth as a factor in the less familiar relations with China’s leaders.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: A delegation from China's Communist Party, led by Li Jianguo, a member of the Politburo, visited the Friendship Tower in the North Korean capital,Pyongyang, in November.

item.title: Plane Skids Into Water at Airport in Bali
item.description: A plane with 108 people onboard skidded off the runway on Saturday, cracked in half and landed in the sea while trying to land.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:credit: Indonesian Search and Rescue Agency, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Rescue teams worked to get passengers out of a Lion Air plane after it slid off the runway into the water at an airport in Bali on Saturday.
